 026: ctypedef np.float64_t DTYPE_t
 027: 
 028: "A parameter for optimizing calculations of adaptive moments by\n"
 029: "cutting off profiles. This parameter is used to decide how many\n"
 030: "sigma^2 into the Gaussian adaptive moment to extend the moment\n"
 031: "calculation, with the weight being defined as 0 beyond this point.\n"
 032: "i.e., if max_moment_nsig2 is set to 25, then the Gaussian is\n"
 033: "extended to (r^2/sigma^2)=25, with proper accounting for elliptical\n"
 034: "geometry.  If this parameter is set to some very large number, then\n"
 035: "the weight is never set to zero and the exponential function is\n"
 036: "always called. Note: GalSim script devel/modules/test_mom_timing.py\n"
 037: "was used to choose a value of 25 as being optimal, in that for the\n"
 038: "cases that were tested, the speedups were typically factors of\n"
 039: "several, but the results of moments and shear estimation were\n"
 040: "changed by <10^-5.  Not all possible cases were checked, and so for\n"
 041: "use of this code for unusual cases, we recommend that users check\n"
 042: "that this value does not affect accuracy, and/or set it to some\n"
 043: "large value to completely disable this optimization.\n"
+044: cdef double MAX_MOMENT_NSIG2 = 25.
  __pyx_v_16adaptive_moments_MAX_MOMENT_NSIG2 = 25.;

 083:     # rho2 = Minv_xx(x-Mx)^2 + 2Minv_xy(x-Mx)(y-My) + Minv_yy(y-My)^2
 084:     # The minimum/maximum y that have a solution rho2 = max_moment_nsig2 is at:
 085:     #   2*Minv_xx*(x-Mx) + 2Minv_xy(y-My) = 0
 086:     # rho2 = Minv_xx (Minv_xy(y-My)/Minv_xx)^2
 087:     #           - 2Minv_xy(Minv_xy(y-My)/Minv_xx)(y-My)
 088:     #           + Minv_yy(y-My)^2
 089:     #      = (Minv_xy^2/Minv_xx - 2Minv_xy^2/Minv_xx + Minv_yy) (y-My)^2
 090:     #      = (Minv_xx Minv_yy - Minv_xy^2)/Minv_xx (y-My)^2
 091:     #      = (1/detM) / Minv_xx (y-My)^2
 092:     #      = (1/Myy) (y-My)^2
 093:     #
 094:     # we are finding the limits for the iy values and then the ix values.

/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_16adaptive_moments_5centered_moment(PyObject *__pyx_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_16adaptive_moments_4centered_moment[] = "Calculate centered moments\n\n    Parameters\n    ----------\n    data : array\n        2d image array\n\n    p, q : int\n        The moments we are interested in. p,q for x,y\n\n    Mx, My : floats\n        The centroids of the image.\n\n    Mxx, Mxy, Myy : floats\n        The second moment weight matrix. See the notes below on the extra\n        factor of two compared to the actual centered moment.\n\n    Returns\n    -------\n    mu_pq : float\n        The centered adaptive moment.\n\n    Notes\n    -----\n    Because of the 2 in eq (5) of Hirata et al 2004, the second moment Ms in\n    the input are /twice/ the value of the centered moments I would obtain\n    otherwise. When you measure ellipticities it generally doesn't matter since\n    you normalize by Mxx + Myy, thus cancelling the factor of two. In my\n    analysis, however, I have kept these separate so this is good to\n    understand.\n\n    ie Mxx = 2 <x^2>, Mxy = 2 <xy>, Myy = 2 <y^2>\n    but Mx = <x>, My = <y>\n\n    consequently the T/2 in (4) = e0 = <x^2> + <y^2>\n\n    ";

 310:     """Calculate centered moments
 311: 
 312:     Parameters
 313:     ----------
 314:     data : array
 315:         2d image array
 316: 
 317:     p, q : int
 318:         The moments we are interested in. p,q for x,y
 319: 
 320:     Mx, My : floats
 321:         The centroids of the image.
 322: 
 323:     Mxx, Mxy, Myy : floats
 324:         The second moment weight matrix. See the notes below on the extra
 325:         factor of two compared to the actual centered moment.
 326: 
 327:     Returns
 328:     -------
 329:     mu_pq : float
 330:         The centered adaptive moment.
 331: 
 332:     Notes
 333:     -----
 334:     Because of the 2 in eq (5) of Hirata et al 2004, the second moment Ms in
 335:     the input are /twice/ the value of the centered moments I would obtain
 336:     otherwise. When you measure ellipticities it generally doesn't matter since
 337:     you normalize by Mxx + Myy, thus cancelling the factor of two. In my
 338:     analysis, however, I have kept these separate so this is good to
 339:     understand.
 340: 
 341:     ie Mxx = 2 <x^2>, Mxy = 2 <xy>, Myy = 2 <y^2>
 342:     but Mx = <x>, My = <y>
 343: 
 344:     consequently the T/2 in (4) = e0 = <x^2> + <y^2>
 345: 
 346:     """
